Crime_Name: Failure to comply with immigration regulations
Legal_Issue: Whether the Court can exercise discretion to hear a moot case following removal from Canada
Application_Facts: Applicant, an Ethiopian citizen, remained in Canada after refusal of her Pre-Removal Risk Assessment (PRRA); she was subsequently removed to Ethiopia
Court_Ruling: Court declined to exercise discretion to hear the moot application
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to depart Canada following PRRA refusal, leading to enforced removal
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged risk upon return to Ethiopia
Legal_Standard: Mootness doctrine: adversarial context, judicial economy, respect for court's role
Assessment_Factor: Existence of adversarial context, availability of practical remedy, risk of creating new legal categories
Applicable_Legislation: IRPA, sections related to PRRA and removal orders
Procedural_Issue: Application filed after removal, rendering it moot
Review_Standard: Reasonableness and jurisdictional limits in moot cases
Legal_Provision_Cited: Sections of IRPA governing PRRA eligibility and removal enforcement
Application_Basis: Seeking quashing of PRRA refusal and stay of removal
Evidence_Assessed: PRRA submission and supporting country condition evidence
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA refusal, stay of removal
Governing_Rule: Court may only hear moot cases if there is live controversy, adversarial interest, and utility in ruling
Harm_Assessment: No irreparable harm established; no effective remedy available post-removal
Cause_Description: PRRA application refused, leading to removal from Canada
Evidence_Handling: Record considered but deemed insufficient to justify hearing a moot case
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions on compliance with removal orders
Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with conditions of stay and removal order
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 112, s. 159, and related PRRA provisions
Jurisdictional_Issue: Courtâ€™s ability to intervene after removal
Decision_Rationale: No practical remedy available; preservation of judicial resources
Decision_Making_Body: Canada Border Services Agency (CBSA), Immigration Division
Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary power to hear moot appeals based on public interest and functional considerations

Violation_Type: Unlawful presence in Canada beyond authorized period
Legal_Issue: Whether the court can hear a judicial review application after the applicant has been removed, rendering the case moot
Application_Facts: Applicant entered Canada multiple times, overstayed visa, withdrew refugee claims, PRRA refused, removed to Ethiopia
Court_Ruling: Court declined to exercise discretion due to mootness and lack of practical remedy
Defendant_Behavior: Repeated entries, withdrawal of claims, failure to comply with immigration status
Legal_Standard: Mootness doctrine: presence of adversarial context, judicial economy, institutional role
Assessment_Factor: No ongoing violation in Canada, inability to provide effective relief
Applicable_Legislation: IRPA, particularly sections on temporary resident status and removal
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated after removal, raising mootness concerns
Review_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied to PRRA decision; mootness affects justiciability
Evidence_Used: Immigration file, PRRA decision, travel history
Application_Basis: Challenge to refusal of humanitarian and compassionate considerations and PRRA
Evidence_Assessed: History of entries, claim withdrawals, and risk assessment in PRRA
Relief_Sought: Quashing of PRRA refusal, stay of removal
Governing_Rule: Courts may not adjudicate moot matters unless exceptional circumstances exist
Harm_Assessment: No irreparable harm demonstrated; removal already executed
Cause_Description: Repeated unauthorized entries, withdrawal of refugee claims, and refusal of PRRA led to removal
Evidence_Handling: Submitted but not fully assessed due to mootness
Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA provisions on temporary resident overstay and removal compliance
Residency_Compliance: Failed to maintain lawful status or comply with removal directive
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 24(1) - status violation; s. 112 - removal order enforcement
Jurisdictional_Issue: Court lacks jurisdiction to grant meaningful relief post-removal
Evidence_Assessment: Considered in procedural context but not determinative due to mootness
Decision_Rationale: No utility in reviewing a concluded matter where applicant is no longer in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary intervention in moot cases based on public interest and functional necessity
